If corporate law firms represent "corporations", and we are facing one of the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, then the surprise is not that the law firm filed for bankruptcy, but that more law firms aren't doing same. Sometimes we seem to forget that the service economy must be coupled in some meaningful way to the real economy. Make no mistake about it, lawyers do not produce a proverbial nail or a horseshoe. Intellectual property oftentimes stem from engineers, computer scientists, etc who produce "real goods". The Dewey & LeBoeuf merger took place just before the recession. So there was only one direction for it to go--down.

The simple fact is that a lot of supposedly smart people (once again) herded themselves to the cliff edge, and then jumped off.

Muddying the waters with your erroneous presumption about the failure of the financial sector being the fault of government meddling, when it was the exact opposite, in the form of relaxed regulation.

Mr. Chandra,

This is my position. You may call it a response and I'm not disputing a word you've written.

1.You speak and write English fluently: I do, and I'm tired of pointing out to Indians that the word revert is not the same as response and that the word revertal is an Indian invention. I am also tired of being told that I am a show off when I speak fluently.

2. You are good at problem solving, thinking outside the box, seeking new ways of doing things: Yes to all of the above. When I do that, I am told that I am crazy. So why bother?

3. You ask questions, engage deeply and question hierarchy: I did not ask too much during my first year with an American apparel company. I was told I was a bit of a yes man. When I did ask during my second year, I was termed "a difficult resource".

4. You take responsibility for your career and for your learning and invest in new skills: I spent long hours preparing for sales, budget and AOP presentations. I upgraded my skills. by manipulating numbers through a mastery of MS Excel.

5. You are professional and ethical: I did not hop jobs. I grew frustrated in companies that did not appreciate these qualities and I didn't paid overtime for those hours as per American company norms. The management that pouted these lines did not have the courage to stand up and look at themselves in the mirror.

I am 42, not a B School graduate, but I can more than hold my own in conversations on a wide range of topics. Where can I send you my CV?
It was delightful and I was in an audience of mixed ages...so, so good...smiled and laughed a whole lot... audience clapping at the end...encore please!!!!!

The article by Prof. Deheja and all the fourteen comments before me are scholarly. I respect each one of them because I have zero knowledge of the science of Economics. Only time will tell who is right.
Mr. Chary, are you a psychic Internet posts reader or something similar? Otherwise, how could you understand the "serious deficiencies" by merely looking at the comments?
It is a sad thing  that many of the comments exhibit the serious deficiencies  Mr Chandra has listed!
Ms Anuradha Sharma is among the best journalists on India Ink. The story is understated, but very nicely reported. I remember one of her previous pieces also being equally good.

We need reformation of the educational system, where creativity is emphasized over rote learning. This requires revolutionary change in the mindset of the faculty and the administration. Equally, a change is needed in the Indian corporate structure from family run businesses to a corporate management structure as in the developed countries. I have personally noticed a deterioration of  English writing and speaking skills that makes it very difficult for recent graduates to participate in the global economy.

My introduction to Nepal was during the 1990 people's power revolution, and it has been most discouraging to witness their dysfunctional democracy.  It has been an object lesson on the limits of government by the people in a very poor country with endemic corruption and low literacy rates.  In my many trips there, I have come to have great respect for the Nepali people and feel sympathy for their dashed hopes for a truly democratic nation.

Locale has nothing to do with it? I beg to differ. I suspect a good fraction of the viewers will end up being expatriate Indians trying to see how the country was portrayed. Pretty normally in fact (much more so than that silly cliche ridden movie that won a bunch of Oscars). It's a nice movie. But having watched it the characters are sober, but really all fairly one dimensional and not that well developed at all. If it hadn't been for the locale this movie would have sunk out of sight early on.

India Ink makes a simplistic suggestion. film locale has little to do with it. Why not just admit that a well-made film, with fabulous actors and an insightful script still has the power to draw? No pyrotechnics, no CGI, no superheroes, no  studied quirkiness, no adolescent boy humor- just a lovely adaptation of a book.

"And it hardly needs mentioning that the judicial branch is now as dysfunctional as the legislative branch. The Supreme Court is essentially another version of the US Senate, composed of old lawyers who vote reliably on strict party lines."

President after President has wished that what you say is true, but it is simply historically not true. Justice Kennedy is viewed as a swing vote but was appointed by Reagan.

"The US Senate is a laughingstock ... where a minority can enforce failure on the majority on every vote .. not just an occasional vote on principal, but every vote .. what do we have here?"

The Democratic party had a filibuster-proof Senate for two years when the House was Democratic and Obama was in the White House and accomplished nothing. They didn't even pass a budget. Don't blame filibuster rules, blame the incompetence of the people elected. And if people truly want a change you'll get 60 Senators from a party and filibusters won't matter.

"Formed to protect slavery and the rights of the wealthy,."

The Founders went to great lengths to LIMIT slavery. They put a block on importation of slaves. They even pushed through the rule knocking down representation for slaves to 3/5 of their number instead of full representation so that the slave States could not push through pro-slavery policies. And it does not protect the rights of the wealthy as much as it protects the right to GET wealthy - as long as you are willing to work to do so.

This is an important piece. We venerate a constitute which enslaved a huge fraction of all people in the country, and which denied voting rights to women. We have a system of presidential election which is far beyond being 'imbecilic' ... it is so unfair as to make a mockery of democracy. Voters in some states have much more power then voters in other states, but that isn't the half of it. Voters in California and Texas are truly meaningless ... I am mystified as to why they bother, since their votes don't really count! What is the chance of California voting majority for a Republican, or Texas voting a majority for a Democrat? None, of course .. so why bother, really. Millions and millions of voters in the four states which have the largest numbers of Americans have no real vote for president ... they are squashed out by being a permanent electoral minority.

And it hardly needs mentioning that the judicial branch is now as dysfunctional as the legislative branch. The Supreme Court is essentially another version of the US Senate, composed of old lawyers who vote reliably on strict party lines. The US Senate is a laughingstock ... where a minority can enforce failure on the majority on every vote .. not just an occasional vote on principal, but every vote .. what do we have here?

The US Constitution? What bunk. Formed to protect slavery and the rights of the wealthy, while giving lip service to universal democratic ideals.

Thank you for this article.

A standing ovation should be given to women like Ms. Wilson. It's obvious that women with sufficient education, determination, and entrepreneurial spirit can do no less than what men can do, and in some way more meaningful given their empathy towards others and willingness to make contribution to the society.

California needs to be divided into four states.

Northern, Central, Coastal and Southern.

Other large states might also benefit by being divided up.

50 states is a nice number, 100 Senators is a nice number

435 Congressmen seems neither nice or necessary.

On to 60 States, 120 Senators and 500 Congressmen.

The California economy is no longer the 8th largest. It has one of the highest unemployment rates and businesses are leaving in droves. The CA model is an example of what *not* to do these days, you are living in the past. It is awash in red ink with no end in sight.

The Constitution has served us well when we actually adhere to it and there is nobody alive today that could do a better job than the framers. Would you leave our fate in the hands of Pelosi and Reid? No thanks.

Greater representation for America's most populous states would also benefit Texas (the second largest) and Florida (the fourth largest, and overtaking New York).  So the political implications of such a move are hardly clear.  Also, it's worth considering that the U.S. Senate, which allows only two votes per state, is far more sensible in its decision-making than those crazies in the House of Reps.  Keep the numbers in the House and Senate as they are.  What needs to be abolished is the Electoral College.  It makes no sense for places like Ohio to decide our next president.

If you add it up, people in twenty-one low population states get twenty one times the representation of California in the U S Senate—42 Senators while California, with the same total population, thirty-seven million, gets 2.

California’s economy is the eighth largest economy in the worl and in many years drives the U S economy. Its outlook is progressive, a viewpoint badly needed in our national legislature, which has blocked or watered down the progressive legislation of the last several decades and opposes most of the policies of the duly elected president. Many of our present political and economic problems stem from the out dated, unfair and unrepresentative electoral system that the constitution has imposed on us.

Our constitution was written for thirteen small coastal Atlantic states 220 years ago, a progressive and revolutionary document then and an inspiration to the world. Many other constitutions have been based on it but with the ability to amend. The founding fathers, angry at George III of England and anxious to block forever the rise of a European-type tyranny set the three branches of government, administrative, legislative, and judicial at each others throats. They were designed not to work together. The FF wanted an arrangement where no one could get hold of all the power. Can we still afford this consensus-blocking arrangement which is ruining our country and may hand the leadership of the world to China in another few decades?

MRIs for back pain are not particlarly useful. What is seen on the study may not be the cause of pain.
All of my patients want them and think that they are being denied good care of their primary doen'torder one right away.

True, the MRI  may not show the cause of back pain, but it will show if the back pain is caused by metastatic CA.  Always best to rule out the stuff that can kill you first.   Late stage ovarian cancer almost always has back pain involved.

So many of these posts ring so true. I have seen so much done to patients that have made them so debilitated. it is truly unreal and sad to see.

And then I have seen the other side, my hospice patients who knew something was wrong but were dismissed until symptoms became so bad that finally someone ordered the right tests and found the cancer in an advanced stage. And too late for any cure.

Cookbook medicine stinks. It all started with DRGs and then managed care came along. Doctors can no longer spend time listening to patients and doing a thorough medical exam. They can no longer order tests that they think are needed. I blame the insurance companies. I do.

Your best bet is to listen to your own body telling you what is wrong. Chest pain needs worked up. Fatique that is sudden and unrelenting needs worked up. Shortness of breath that is new needs attention. Changes in your bowel habits or any black stool---needs worked up. Back pain that cannot be explained and continues needs an MRI. Too many of my cancer patients had back pain that was dismissed. You know when something seems wrong. Don't be an alarmist, but when it continues to nag at you that is when you should have it checked out.

Small moles that were mentioned in another post that were removed, well, better safe than sorry. However, the last 4 melanoma cases I saw were areas on the scalp and thigh that were scaly and itcy. No moles. So have that checked as well.

We have to be our own best advocates.

The Constitution only addresses the qualifications for the office of President and Vice President. It does not in any way say how they were to be chosen. Why should it say that?
We have the primary mess because the parties chose to become more 'democratic' in delegate and candidate selection.
Party conventions were once where the candidate was actually selected instead of a large celebration of the choice, complete with balloon drop and spousal kisses.
The 'smoke-filled room' of invisible dealing and compromising gave way to a very boring circus or coronation.
It sure would be simpler to keep track of only one national legislature.

I believe the Presidential Primary systems are controlled by the parties themselves.

Considering the government already has their hands in way too many things, I would prefer they lay off this.

We can't just use the government as a tool to suit ourselves. We need to establish the constitution as it should be, this doesn't mean roll back anyone's rights but the Fed needs to roll back some of it's power grabs.

Dr. Levinson's suggestions as to how the constitution perhaps should be changed would make us worse off, not better:  1. The elected judiciaries in most states are often of much lower quality than federal appointed judges, especially, as in Texas, if they run as Republicans or Democrats.  Granted, being "electorally accountable" does not necessarily mean being directly elected  2.  Giving legislatures more power is frightening.  The caliber of these people is getting lower and lower, and they are getting more partisan and corrupt.  3. More direct democracy is also scary.  California is a perfect example as to why initiatives are a really bad idea.  (For one, they have totally been captured by special interests, and often contradictory measures are passed.)  If we had non-gerimandered districts where moderates and centrists had some chance of winning elections, that could go a long way to fix things.  That would be a great constitutional amendment.   4. An amendment to fix the primary presidential primary system would also be of large benefit.  I don't know exactly how that could be done, but I do know we have a crazy way of selecting presidential candidates, including after finally getting the nominees then having them lambast each other for six months through all sorts of media.  Drives me crazy.
